newsitem.title: USA: U.S. EIA tones down concern over distillate stocks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. EIA tones down concern over distillate stocks.

text.p: Although U.S. distillate stocks are still lower than average for this time of year, the Energy Information Administration said Wednesday it was less concerned about supplies than at the beginning of the winter.
"While they are still well below the average seasonal level, with the coldest part of winter yet to go, this does represent a significant improvement from the pre-season situation," EIA said.
U.S. distillate stocks, including heating oil and diesel, at the end of January stood at 114.2 million barrels, topping year-earlier levels for the first time this winter.

Refiners were able to build their depleted stocks in December with mild temperatures holding demand below last winter's levels and production soaring to "unprecedented levels," EIA said in material presented at an Independent Petroleum Association of America conference in New Orleans.

Distillate production from last July onward has been higher than the average over the last five years, peaking in November at more than 3.65 million barrels per day, compared with an average winter peak of less than 3.3 million bpd.
The EIA comments were released in Washington.
